channel.title: Example on Home
channel.description: Recent content in Example on Home

item.title: Chrome Extension by Kotlin Js
item.description:
This post is about the Uniqlo CN Chrome Extension which I created just for fun :) Different parts of the code are described by the following four posts.

  • 1. Common (Coming soon)
  • 2. Content (Coming soon)
  • 3. Background (Coming soon)
  • 4. Wrap-up (Coming soon)

Build

  • 1. Clone or download source code from github
  • 2. Go to the folder which contains the source code and run ./gradlew clean build. A dist folder will be created after the build.

Install

  • 1. Click Window -> Extensions or type chrome://extensions/ to open the Extensions window
  • 2. Turn on Developer mode of chrome
  • 3. Click Load unpacked button and select the dist folder of this project

What it does

  • 1. Open any of the item of Uniqlo CN site. e.g. this one
  • 2. Click the extension button with Uniqlo logo located at the top right corner.
  • 3. It will add the converted price and the link of the same item of Australian site in the page.

Reference:

  • 1. Chrome Extension Get Started Tutorial
  • 2. How to Make a Chrome Extension
  • 3. Kotlin Fullstack Sample
  • 4. Working with Javascript
  • 5. index.d.ts
  • 6. Stackoverflow
  • 7. Foreign Exchange Rates API

item.title: Java 8 forEach with Index
item.description:
Say you have a List of Item. You use the Java 8 API forEach to iterate over the list and print the items.

List<Item> items = ...
items.forEach(System.out::println);

Output:

Item{name='apple', quantity=6}
Item{name='orange', quantity=12}
Item{name='kiwi', quantity=8}
Item{name='banana', quantity=4}

Now you would like to print the items along with the index. Apparently forEach doesn’t provide index.

One trick is to use IntStream.range as shown below.

IntStream.range(0, items.size())
                .forEach(i -> System.out.println(String.format(" %d -> %s", i+1, items.get(i))));

Output:

 1 -> Item{name='apple', quantity=6}
 2 -> Item{name='orange', quantity=12}
 3 -> Item{name='kiwi', quantity=8}
 4 -> Item{name='banana', quantity=4}
Another way is to use the plain old for loop which will always work in this case :) 
for (int i = 0; i < items.size(); i++)
            System.out.println(String.format(" %d -> %s", i+1, items.get(i)));

Here is the full source:

package example;

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;
import java.util.stream.IntStream;

public class ForeachTest {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        List<Item> items = Arrays.asList(
                new Item("apple", 6),
                new Item("orange", 12),
                new Item("kiwi", 8),
                new Item("banana", 4)
        );

        items.forEach(System.out::println);

        System.out.println("forEach: ");
        IntStream.range(0, items.size())
                .forEach(i -> System.out.println(String.format(" %d -> %s", i+1, items.get(i))));

        System.out.println("plain old for loop: ");
        for (int i = 0; i < items.size(); i++)
            System.out.println(String.format(" %d -> %s", i+1, items.get(i)));

    }

    public static class Item {
        private String name;
        private int quantity;

        public String getName() {
            return name;
        }

        public void setName(String name) {
            this.name = name;
        }

        public int getQuantity() {
            return quantity;
        }

        public void setQuantity(int quantity) {
            this.quantity = quantity;
        }

        public Item(String name, int quantity) {
            this.name = name;
            this.quantity = quantity;
        }

        @Override
        public String toString() {
            return "Item{" +
                    "name='" + name + '\'' +
                    ", quantity=" + quantity +
                    '}';
        }
    }
}

Output:

Item{name='apple', quantity=6}
Item{name='orange', quantity=12}
Item{name='kiwi', quantity=8}
Item{name='banana', quantity=4}
forEach: 
 1 -> Item{name='apple', quantity=6}
 2 -> Item{name='orange', quantity=12}
 3 -> Item{name='kiwi', quantity=8}
 4 -> Item{name='banana', quantity=4}
plain old for loop: 
 1 -> Item{name='apple', quantity=6}
 2 -> Item{name='orange', quantity=12}
 3 -> Item{name='kiwi', quantity=8}
 4 -> Item{name='banana', quantity=4}

Reference:

  • 1. Iterable
  • 2. IntStream

item.title: Kotlin Collections SQL Group By
item.description:
In Java 8 Stream SQL Group By we explored how to perform SQL similar group by and aggregation by using Java 8 stream API. This time we’re going to do it in Kotlin.

First of all, we use Kotlin Data Class to implement our Data class. As you can easily tell, it’s much shorter than the Java equivalent.

        
        
data class Data(val dcId: String, val dbGroup: String, val week: String, var acctVal: Long, var shopVal: Long, var partVal: Long, var backVal: Long) {
    fun merge(other: Data): Data {
        this.acctVal += other.acctVal;
        this.shopVal += other.shopVal;
        this.partVal += other.partVal;
        this.backVal += other.backVal;
        return this;
    }
}

We use the listof to initialize our test data, which is similar to Arrays.asList Java API.

Our calculation starts from groupBy which takes a lambda expression { it.dcId } as parameter to specify the groupBy key. After that we will get a Map<String, List<Data>>, where the key is dcId and value is a list of Data associated with the key.

Then we use mapValues to process the grouped list of Data further. It accepts a transform function. In this function { it.value.groupBy { it.dbGroup } } we use groupBy again to further group data by dbGroup. After that we will get a Map<String, Map<String, List<Data>>>.

We do the same to group data by week further. At this stage we are done with groupBy. We now use reduce to aggregation grouped data.

        
        
data.groupBy { it.dcId /* it: Data */ }
    .mapValues { /* it: Map.Entry<String, List<Data>> */
        it.value.groupBy { it.dbGroup /* it: Data */ }
                .mapValues { /* it: Map.Entry<String, List<Data>> */
                    it.value.groupBy { it.week /* it: Data */ }
                            .mapValues { /* it: Map.Entry<String, List<Data>> */
                                it.value.reduce(Data::merge)
                            }
                }
    }

Finally we use flatMap and map to collect the result list.

        
        
.flatMap { /* it: Map.Entry<String, Map<String, Map<String, Data>>> */
    it.value.flatMap { /* it: Map.Entry<String, Map<String, Data>> */
                it.value.map { /* it: Map.Entry<String, Data> */
                            it.value
                        }
            }
}

Here is the full source: 

        
        
data class Data(val dcId: String, val dbGroup: String, val week: String, var acctVal: Long, var shopVal: Long, var partVal: Long, var backVal: Long) {
    fun merge(other: Data): Data {
        this.acctVal += other.acctVal;
        this.shopVal += other.shopVal;
        this.partVal += other.partVal;
        this.backVal += other.backVal;
        return this;
    }
}

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
    val data = listOf(
            Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week1", 111L, 211L, 311L, 411L),
            Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week1", 121L, 221L, 321L, 421L),
            Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week1", 131L, 231L, 331L, 431L),
            Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week1", 141L, 241L, 341L, 441L),
            Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week2", 112L, 212L, 312L, 412L),
            Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week2", 122L, 222L, 322L, 422L),
            Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week2", 132L, 232L, 332L, 432L),
            Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week2", 142L, 242L, 342L, 442L),
            Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week1", 111L, 211L, 311L, 411L),
            Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week1", 121L, 221L, 321L, 421L),
            Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week1", 131L, 231L, 331L, 431L),
            Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week1", 141L, 241L, 341L, 441L),
            Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week2", 112L, 212L, 312L, 412L),
            Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week2", 122L, 222L, 322L, 422L),
            Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week2", 132L, 232L, 332L, 432L),
            Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week2", 142L, 242L, 342L, 442L)
    )

    println("Before merge:")
    data.forEach { println(it) }
    val mergedData /* : List<Data> */ = data.groupBy { it.dcId /* it: Data */ }
            .mapValues { /* it: Map.Entry<String, List<Data>> */
                it.value.groupBy { it.dbGroup /* it: Data */ }
                        .mapValues { /* it: Map.Entry<String, List<Data>> */
                            it.value.groupBy { it.week /* it: Data */ }
                                    .mapValues { /* it: Map.Entry<String, List<Data>> */
                                        it.value.reduce(Data::merge)
                                    }
                        }
            }
            .flatMap { /* it: Map.Entry<String, Map<String, Map<String, Data>>> */
                it.value.flatMap { /* it: Map.Entry<String, Map<String, Data>> */
                            it.value.map { /* it: Map.Entry<String, Data> */
                                        it.value
                                    }
                        }
            }
    println("After merge:")
    mergedData.forEach { println(it) }
}

Reference:

  • 1. Kotlin Data Class
  • 2. Kotlin Collections

item.title: Java 8 Stream Set to Map
item.description:
Say you have a Set of Student.

Set<Student> studentSet = ...

[Student{id='02', first='John', last='Hay'}
, Student{id='03', first='Matt', last='Simpson'}
, Student{id='01', first='Dick', last='Smith'}
]

You would like to convert it into a Map where key is the ID of the Student and value is the Student object itself.

Here is how it can be done by using Java 8 Stream API.

Map<String, Student> map = studentSet.stream()
                                .collect(Collectors.toMap(Student::getId,
                                            Function.identity()));

Output:

{01=Student{id='01', first='Dick', last='Smith'}
, 02=Student{id='02', first='John', last='Hay'}
, 03=Student{id='03', first='Matt', last='Simpson'}
}

Collectors.toMap is used to collect the stream as Map.

The first argument is a mapping Function to produce keys. Here method reference Student::getId is specified. Semantically it is the same as the lambda expression student -> student.getId().

The second argument is a mapping Function to produce values. Here Function.identity is used which is semantically the same as the lambda expression student -> student.

Here is the full source:

package example;

import java.util.HashSet;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.Set;
import java.util.function.Function;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;

public class SetToMapTest {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Set<Student> studentSet = new HashSet<>();
        studentSet.add(new Student("01", "Dick", "Smith"));
        studentSet.add(new Student("02", "John", "Hay"));
        studentSet.add(new Student("03", "Matt", "Simpson"));
        System.out.println(studentSet);

        Map<String, Student> map = studentSet.stream()
                .collect(Collectors.toMap(Student::getId,
                        Function.identity()));

        System.out.println(map);
    }

    public static class Student {
        private String id;
        private String first;
        private String last;

        public String getId() {
            return id;
        }

        public void setId(String id) {
            this.id = id;
        }

        public String getFirst() {
            return first;
        }

        public void setFirst(String first) {
            this.first = first;
        }

        public String getLast() {
            return last;
        }

        public void setLast(String last) {
            this.last = last;
        }

        public Student(String id, String first, String last) {
            this.id = id;
            this.first = first;
            this.last = last;
        }

        @Override
        public String toString() {
            return "Student{" +
                    "id='" + id + '\'' +
                    ", first='" + first + '\'' +
                    ", last='" + last + '\'' +
                    "}\n";
        }
    }
}

Output:

[Student{id='02', first='John', last='Hay'}
, Student{id='03', first='Matt', last='Simpson'}
, Student{id='01', first='Dick', last='Smith'}
]
{01=Student{id='01', first='Dick', last='Smith'}
, 02=Student{id='02', first='John', last='Hay'}
, 03=Student{id='03', first='Matt', last='Simpson'}
}

Reference:

  • 1. Java 8 Collectors

item.title: Java 8 Stream SQL Group By
item.description:
This is a scenario that I faced in the real world. I had to query data from multiple sources and merge/aggregate by multiple fields manually.

Here is how I solved it by using Java 8 stream API.

Firstly, Collectors.groupingBy is used nestly to group by the three fields.

The first argument is a Function which representing the classifier. Here method reference Data::getDcId is specified. Semantically it is the same as the lambda expression data -> data.getDcId().

The second argument let us specify another Collector which is called a downstream collector.

data.stream()
        .collect(Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getDcId,
                Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getDbGroup,
                Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getWeek,

Then Collectors.reducing is used to aggregate grouped data. The argument is a BinaryOperator which is a specialization of BiFunction where the two operands and the result are all of the same type.

data.stream()
        .collect(
            ...
                Collectors.reducing(Data::merge)))))

At this stage Map<String, Map<String, Map<String, Optional<Data>>>> is returned. flatMap is used twice to convert the nested map to a Optional<Data> stream.

data.stream()
        .collect(
            ...
                )
    .values().stream()
                .flatMap(v -> v.values().stream())
                .flatMap(v -> v.values().stream())

We also want to get an ordered result. So sorted is used to sort the result stream. To specify multiple fields to sort on, Comparator.comparing combined with thenComparing are used as shown below.

.sorted(Comparator.comparing(Data::getDcId)
            .thenComparing(Comparator.comparing(Data::getDbGroup))
            .thenComparing(Comparator.comparing(Data::getWeek)))

Finally, we collect the result stream as list by using Collectors.toList.

public static void main(String[] args) {
    List<Data> data = Arrays.asList(
            new Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week1", 111L, 211L, 311L, 411L),
            new Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week1", 121L, 221L, 321L, 421L),
            new Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week1", 131L, 231L, 331L, 431L),
            new Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week1", 141L, 241L, 341L, 441L),
            new Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week2", 112L, 212L, 312L, 412L),
            new Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week2", 122L, 222L, 322L, 422L),
            new Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week2", 132L, 232L, 332L, 432L),
            new Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week2", 142L, 242L, 342L, 442L),
            new Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week1", 111L, 211L, 311L, 411L),
            new Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week1", 121L, 221L, 321L, 421L),
            new Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week1", 131L, 231L, 331L, 431L),
            new Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week1", 141L, 241L, 341L, 441L),
            new Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week2", 112L, 212L, 312L, 412L),
            new Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week2", 122L, 222L, 322L, 422L),
            new Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week2", 132L, 232L, 332L, 432L),
            new Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week2", 142L, 242L, 342L, 442L)
    );
    System.out.println("Before merge:");
    data.forEach(System.out::println);
    List<Data> mergedData = data.stream()
        .collect(Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getDcId,
                Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getDbGroup,
                Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getWeek,
                        Collectors.reducing(Data::merge)))))
        .values().stream()
                .flatMap(v -> v.values().stream())
                .flatMap(v -> v.values().stream())
                .map(Optional::get)
                .sorted(Comparator.comparing(Data::getDcId)
                        .thenComparing(Comparator.comparing(Data::getDbGroup))
                        .thenComparing(Comparator.comparing(Data::getWeek)))
                .collect(Collectors.toList());
    System.out.println("After merge:");
    mergedData.forEach(System.out::println);
}

Output:

Before merge:
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week1', acctVal=111, shopVal=211, partVal=311, backVal=411}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week1', acctVal=121, shopVal=221, partVal=321, backVal=421}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week1', acctVal=131, shopVal=231, partVal=331, backVal=431}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week1', acctVal=141, shopVal=241, partVal=341, backVal=441}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week2', acctVal=112, shopVal=212, partVal=312, backVal=412}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week2', acctVal=122, shopVal=222, partVal=322, backVal=422}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week2', acctVal=132, shopVal=232, partVal=332, backVal=432}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week2', acctVal=142, shopVal=242, partVal=342, backVal=442}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week1', acctVal=111, shopVal=211, partVal=311, backVal=411}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week1', acctVal=121, shopVal=221, partVal=321, backVal=421}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week1', acctVal=131, shopVal=231, partVal=331, backVal=431}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week1', acctVal=141, shopVal=241, partVal=341, backVal=441}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week2', acctVal=112, shopVal=212, partVal=312, backVal=412}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week2', acctVal=122, shopVal=222, partVal=322, backVal=422}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week2', acctVal=132, shopVal=232, partVal=332, backVal=432}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week2', acctVal=142, shopVal=242, partVal=342, backVal=442}
After merge:
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week1', acctVal=242, shopVal=442, partVal=642, backVal=842}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week2', acctVal=244, shopVal=444, partVal=644, backVal=844}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week1', acctVal=262, shopVal=462, partVal=662, backVal=862}
Data{dcId='dc000', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week2', acctVal=264, shopVal=464, partVal=664, backVal=864}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week1', acctVal=242, shopVal=442, partVal=642, backVal=842}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup01', week='week2', acctVal=244, shopVal=444, partVal=644, backVal=844}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week1', acctVal=262, shopVal=462, partVal=662, backVal=862}
Data{dcId='dc001', dbGroup='dbGroup02', week='week2', acctVal=264, shopVal=464, partVal=664, backVal=864}

Here is the full source:

package example;

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.Comparator;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Optional;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;

public class DataGroupByTest {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        List<Data> data = Arrays.asList(
                new Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week1", 111L, 211L, 311L, 411L),
                new Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week1", 121L, 221L, 321L, 421L),
                new Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week1", 131L, 231L, 331L, 431L),
                new Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week1", 141L, 241L, 341L, 441L),
                new Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week2", 112L, 212L, 312L, 412L),
                new Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week2", 122L, 222L, 322L, 422L),
                new Data("dc000", "dbGroup01", "week2", 132L, 232L, 332L, 432L),
                new Data("dc000", "dbGroup02", "week2", 142L, 242L, 342L, 442L),
                new Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week1", 111L, 211L, 311L, 411L),
                new Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week1", 121L, 221L, 321L, 421L),
                new Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week1", 131L, 231L, 331L, 431L),
                new Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week1", 141L, 241L, 341L, 441L),
                new Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week2", 112L, 212L, 312L, 412L),
                new Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week2", 122L, 222L, 322L, 422L),
                new Data("dc001", "dbGroup01", "week2", 132L, 232L, 332L, 432L),
                new Data("dc001", "dbGroup02", "week2", 142L, 242L, 342L, 442L)
        );
        System.out.println("Before merge:");
        data.forEach(System.out::println);
        List<Data> mergedData = data.stream().collect(Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getDcId,
                Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getDbGroup,
                        Collectors.groupingBy(Data::getWeek,
                                Collectors.reducing(Data::merge)))))
                .values().stream()
                            .flatMap(v -> v.values().stream())
                            .flatMap(v -> v.values().stream())
                            .map(Optional::get)
                            .sorted(Comparator.comparing(Data::getDcId)
                                    .thenComparing(Comparator.comparing(Data::getDbGroup))
                                    .thenComparing(Comparator.comparing(Data::getWeek)))
                            .collect(Collectors.toList());
        System.out.println("After merge:");
        mergedData.forEach(System.out::println);
    }

    public static class Data {
        private String dcId;
        private String dbGroup;
        private String week;
        private Long acctVal;
        private Long shopVal;
        private Long partVal;
        private Long backVal;

        public String getDcId() {
            return dcId;
        }

        public void setDcId(String dcId) {
            this.dcId = dcId;
        }

        public String getDbGroup() {
            return dbGroup;
        }

        public void setDbGroup(String dbGroup) {
            this.dbGroup = dbGroup;
        }

        public String getWeek() {
            return week;
        }

        public void setWeek(String week) {
            this.week = week;
        }

        public Long getAcctVal() {
            return acctVal;
        }

        public void setAcctVal(Long acctVal) {
            this.acctVal = acctVal;
        }

        public Long getShopVal() {
            return shopVal;
        }

        public void setShopVal(Long shopVal) {
            this.shopVal = shopVal;
        }

        public Long getPartVal() {
            return partVal;
        }

        public void setPartVal(Long partVal) {
            this.partVal = partVal;
        }

        public Long getBackVal() {
            return backVal;
        }

        public void setBackVal(Long backVal) {
            this.backVal = backVal;
        }

        public Data(String dcId, String dbGroup, String week, Long acctVal, Long shopVal, Long partVal, Long backVal) {
            this.dcId = dcId;
            this.dbGroup = dbGroup;
            this.week = week;
            this.acctVal = acctVal;
            this.shopVal = shopVal;
            this.partVal = partVal;
            this.backVal = backVal;
        }

        public Data merge(Data other) {
            this.acctVal = this.acctVal + other.acctVal;
            this.shopVal = this.shopVal + other.shopVal;
            this.partVal = this.partVal + other.partVal;
            this.backVal = this.backVal + other.backVal;
            return this;
        }

        @Override
        public String toString() {
            return "Data{" +
                    "dcId='" + dcId + '\'' +
                    ", dbGroup='" + dbGroup + '\'' +
                    ", week='" + week + '\'' +
                    ", acctVal=" + acctVal +
                    ", shopVal=" + shopVal +
                    ", partVal=" + partVal +
                    ", backVal=" + backVal +
                    '}';
        }
    }
}

Reference:

  • 1. Java 8 Collectors

item.title: Hugo Rust Shortcodes Example
item.description:
This is the live demo page for the {{< rust >}} hugo shortcode

https://github.com/sam-ma/hugo-shortcodes

fn main() {
    println!("Hello, world!");
}
#fn main() {

item.title: Hugo Kotlin Shortcodes Example
item.description:
This is the live demo page for the {{< kotlin >}} hugo shortcode

https://github.com/sam-ma/hugo-shortcodes

        
        
class Contact(val id: Int, var email: String) 

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
    val contact = Contact(1, "mary@gmail.com")
    println(contact.id)                   
}

    println("Hello World!")

import org.junit.Test
import org.junit.Assert

class TestExtensionFunctions() {
    @Test fun testIntExtension() {
        Assert.assertEquals("Rational number creation error: ", RationalNumber(4, 1), 4.r())
    }

    @Test fun testPairExtension() {
        Assert.assertEquals("Rational number creation error: ", RationalNumber(2, 3), Pair(2, 3).r())
    }
}
//sampleStart
/*
Then implement extension functions Int.r() and Pair.r() and make them convert Int and Pair to RationalNumber.
*/
fun Int.r(): RationalNumber = RationalNumber(this, 2)
fun Pair<Int, Int>.r(): RationalNumber = RationalNumber(first, second)

data class RationalNumber(val numerator: Int, val denominator: Int)
//sampleEnd

        
    

        
        
import org.junit.Test
import org.junit.Assert

class TestContainsFunctions() {
    @Test fun contains() {
        Assert.assertTrue(containsEven(listOf(1, 2, 3, 4)));
    }
    @Test fun notContains() {
        Assert.assertFalse(containsEven(listOf(1, 3, 5)));
    }
}
//sampleStart
/*
Pass a lambda to any function to check if the collection contains an even number.
The function any gets a predicate as an argument and returns true if there is at least one element satisfying the predicate.
*/
fun containsEven(collection: Collection<Int>): Boolean = collection.any {[mark]TODO()[/mark]}
//sampleEnd

        
    

        
        
package fancylines


import jquery.*
import org.w3c.dom.CanvasRenderingContext2D
import org.w3c.dom.HTMLCanvasElement
import kotlin.browser.document
import kotlin.browser.window
import kotlin.js.Math



val canvas = initalizeCanvas()
fun initalizeCanvas(): HTMLCanvasElement {
    val canvas = document.createElement("canvas") as HTMLCanvasElement
    val context = canvas.getContext("2d") as CanvasRenderingContext2D
    context.canvas.width  = window.innerWidth.toInt();
    context.canvas.height = window.innerHeight.toInt();
    document.body!!.appendChild(canvas)
    return canvas
}

class FancyLines() {
    val context = canvas.getContext("2d") as CanvasRenderingContext2D
    val height = canvas.height
    val width = canvas.width
    var x = width * Math.random()
    var y = height * Math.random()
    var hue = 0;

    fun line() {
        context.save();

        context.beginPath();

        context.lineWidth = 20.0 * Math.random();
        context.moveTo(x, y);

        x = width * Math.random();
        y = height * Math.random();

        context.bezierCurveTo(width * Math.random(), height * Math.random(),
                width * Math.random(), height * Math.random(), x, y);

        hue += (Math.random() * 10).toInt();

        context.strokeStyle = "hsl($hue, 50%, 50%)";

        context.shadowColor = "white";
        context.shadowBlur = 10.0;

        context.stroke();

        context.restore();
    }

    fun blank() {
        context.fillStyle = "rgba(255,255,1,0.1)";
        context.fillRect(0.0, 0.0, width.toDouble(), height.toDouble());
    }

    fun run() {
        window.setInterval({ line() }, 40);
        window.setInterval({ blank() }, 100);
    }
}
//sampleStart
fun main(args: Array<String>) {
    FancyLines().run()
}
//sampleEnd
